docs.lead_paragraph: When governments make promises they can’t pay for, something has to give. That something can be tax breaks.

headline.seo: Tax Breaks to Take Before They Are Gone
headline.main: Tax Breaks to Take Before They Go
headline.print_headline: Tax Breaks To Take Before They Go

docs.snippet: When governments make promises they can’t pay for, something has to give. That something can be tax breaks.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, President Obama directed the Justice Department to stop defending the law that bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages. And while the decision will -- and should -- be celebrated by gay couples across the country, practically speaking, their lives won't change much for some time. After all, the move doesn't actually repeal the so-called Defense of Marriage Act. So same-sex couples will still remain strangers, for the most part, in the eyes of the federal government. Couples will still be unable to jointly file their federal tax returns, and they won't be eligible to receive Social Security benefits based on their spouse's earnings record.
docs.abstract: Bucks blog; President Obama directs Justice Department to stop defending law that bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether you have health insurance at home or not, if you visit Panama you'll get free coverage for 30 days under a program that the country began last month.

docs.lead_paragraph: David Cay Johnston has a terrific piece up about the nonsense of comparing government workers to private-sector counterparts by claiming that the government pays for more of their benefits. As he says,

On Feb. 16, thousands of protesters, including many teachers, flooded the Wisconsin Capitol building to confront Gov. Scott Walker. School was canceled because of teacher absenteeism, and many Democratic state legislators also avoided work and purposely missed a voting deadline to send a message about their sentiments.
